text: let the massive internet over-critique begin!
<@U06DFL7BP|charlesv> has joined the channel
IT BAD, IT DUMB

(I’m sure they have a lot of talented people who did a lot of hard work on it, but losing the serifs makes that L feel claustrophobic, along with tight kerning in general, and the slanted bottom of the ‘e’’s eye feels like a gag)
the ‘G’ logo however is a great improvement over the ‘lowercase g on a blue background'
now that you’ve described the l as claustrophobic, i cringe at that poor little green stick.  :disappointed:
“I’ll forget it ever changed by 6pm” is probably the most accurate critique  i’ve heard so far
i like it tbh, but it reminds me of eBay
<@U06DFL7BP|charlesv> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/charlesv/F0A07AFS7/pasted_image_at_2015_09_01_09_16_am.png|Pasted image at 2015-09-01, 9:16 AM>
loool
that logo still cracks me up
it’s such a 90s barf
any logo with mixed primary colors just looks like a kid’s toy brand to me
<— mommy critique
dad critique is shared ^^
I don't mind things once it starts moving around, but the logotype itself is pretty meh.

There's a funny thing happening with companies like them, where they need to have a system that conveys either a singular thing (a mark) or somehow adapt to everything they do (motion, variations for branches, etc).
but also - I'll forget it changed by 10am.
i like it. I was never a fan of the old one though. This new mark seems very intended for movement and animation.
this looks like it would be a good addition to our library <http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2015/03/real-life-responsive-web-design-smashing-book-5/>

attachments.title: That's Real-Life Responsive Web Design: Meet The Brand New Smashing Book 5 – Smashing Magazine
attachments.text: Smart “responsive” workflows, effective responsive design/UX patterns and powerful front-end techniques — if you need a good book on smart responsive design, our brand new Smashing Book 5 is just what you need. Neatly packed in a gorgeous hardcover, it covers time-saving, practical techniques for crafting fast, maintainable and scalable responsive websites. 584 (!) pages. Hardcover/eBook. Pre-order the book and save 15% today. Responsive design is a default these days, but we are all still figuring out just the right process and techniques to better craft responsive websites. That’s why we created a new book — to gather practical techniques and strategies from people who have learned how to get things done right, in actual projects with actual real-world challenges.
attachments.fallback: Smashing Magazine: That's Real-Life Responsive Web Design: Meet The Brand New Smashing Book 5 – Smashing Magazine

text: :thumbsup:

Some behind the scenes… Looks pretty great in context.
<https://design.google.com/articles/evolving-the-google-identity/>

attachments.title: Evolving the Google Identity
attachments.text: At Google we say, “Focus on the user and all else will follow.” With this in mind, we seek to design experiences that inspire and enlighten our users.
attachments.fallback: Google Design: Evolving the Google Identity

text: Man, I love how openly and thoroughly Google has been writing about their design process / decisions lately
Totally, thinking back to the last “great re-brand” case-study (AirBnb), this one is so much more thoughtful.
It’s true, yeah. AirBnB just peppered theirs with nice lifestyle photos / videos to try and make up for it
i love that they even talk about optimizing their logo asset for low bandwidth users. I love that that criteria really did inform the both the design and the implementation.
I like the new mark just fine, but I’ve always felt like Google was better at talking about design than actually doing it.
i used to think that until the past year or so. they’ve really stepped up their game. Nothing mind blowing, but graceful, thoughtful, and a massive improvement over their previous efforts.
oh for sure - the change over the last three years especially has been massive
(insert snarky comment about the rise of design at google post Marissa Meyer)
I give Google an A+ for effort and a B- for consistent implementation

They fall short of making their own products consistent (at all), and in things like the guidelines for material design are better than the competitors (looking at you apple) - but don’t always provide clear, granular detail
BUT - I am hoping that their success lights a fire for folks like apple, and inspires others to invest in design
draplin approved <https://twitter.com/draplin/status/638779083703341056>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/Draplin|@Draplin>: DDC9289: My name is Aaron James Draplin and I for one am very happy with the new <https://twitter.com/google|@google> wordmark update. About time! #yay #clean #welcoming

text: I will submit that Google HAS to do things like design guidelines more than Apple because they lack a culture of design - which is why their implementation is checkered.
That said, Apple could perhaps use more of this - ESPECIALLY around their software
the HIG stopped iterating on most of its interaction design pre-iPad. and the iPad portion of the guidelines has ALWAYS suuuuuucked.
and the last iteration of the visual design was really iOS7. (sigh)
it always stuck in my craw that they traditionally only have 1-2 sessions in the entirety of WWDC that are for non-coding designers.
you put those two things in context, and it is shocking the lack of support apple provides for it’s app design community
they also go through UI evangelists like a box of kleenex.
But...apple music!
ha
:simple_smile:
omg. was just messing with the music.app this morning. THE HORROR
its awful
but i am still using it because i quit rdio
yeah it sucks, and i still use it also
i can only hope that there is a team of UI designers working on it at this very moment
yeah, i keep coming back to it too.
they need to split it into several apps - or finally admit that the information architecture for app navigation in iOS DOES NOT SCALE
(hamburger)

I will say this - while they’ve failed at a lot of things software/service related - I do appreciate what I perceive to be their underlying goal which seems to be unifying things that are conceptually similar and trying to reduce the number “buckets” users have to turn to
ooooh <https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/spa/ra93brplpldred1/8td1o74c.png>
wow
um.
ouch.
a good reminder of the importance of context :confounded: <http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/world/europe/at-auschwitz-mist-to-cool-visitors-is-a-grim-reminder-to-some.html>
